LLM capabilities are doubling every 7 months…

LLM capabilities are doubling every 7 months…

Here’s the most important LLM benchmark I’ve come across 👇 

A couple of months ago, the team at METR released a new AI benchmark.

Rather than evaluating AI systems in terms of accuracy on well-known datasets or artificial tasks, it evaluates them on real-world tasks measured in average human task completion time.

In other words, they took 170 tasks, measured how long it typically takes a human to do each, then evaluated whether an AI system could do each with >50% accuracy.

Current models can easily handle “1-hour tasks,” e.g. write simple ETL scripts, set up a software package.

However, the most notable finding was that these capabilities have been accelerating over the past 6 years, approximately doubling every 7 months.

Extrapolating out, this means that models will be able to do…
… 1-day tasks in 2026
… 1-week tasks in 2027
… 1-month tasks in 2029 😳 

It’s hard to imagine what the consequences will be if LLMs can do a month’s worth of work!

What do you think 2029 will look like?

--

7 Basic AI Terms (Simply) Explained…

7 Basic AI Terms (Simply) Explained…

1) Large Language Model (LLM)
 = Software that can perform arbitrary tasks via natural language.

When people talk about AI today, they are typically talking about LLMs.

2) Prompt
 = The request you pass to an LLM

This is the mechanism for using LLMs.

3) Prompt engineering
= Crafting your prompt to optimize task performance

While most tasks can be completed by simply asking, there are a few key tricks for making specific tasks better and more reliable.

4) Inference
= Using an LLM to generate text

This is like the autocomplete on your phone, but very powerful and on repeat.

5) Token 
= A unit of text that an LLM can understand

We see text as words and characters. LLMs see them as tokens e.g. "Here", " are", " some", " examples", " of", " tokens!

6) Context Window
= The maximum amount of text an LLM can process

For modern LLMs, this is about ~100k words (i.e. the length of a typical book).

7) Parameters
= Numbers that determine what the LLM generates given the input

Small" LLMs have around 1B of these numbers. Bigger ones will have 100B+


What are some other basic terms that I should add?

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 5/5)

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 5/5)

What is Reinforcement Learning (RL)?

The most common type of machine learning is supervised learning, which involves programming computers by example.

However, this is not the only way computers can learn about the world… 

... they can also interact with it.

This is how RL works, which allows computers to learn through trial and error.

The promise of RL is that models are not bound by human labelling or expertise.

A landmark example is AlphaGo, a deep neural network trained via RL to play the game of Go, and eventually surpassed human grandmaster performance.

Today, RL may be the key to more powerful AI agents, enabling systems to go beyond existing human knowledge and make novel discoveries 🧑‍🔬 


That ends my short series on ML Foundations for AI Engineers. If you want to learn more, check out my blog post on Medium: https://lnkd.in/g7Ux7bSr

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 3/5)

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 3/5)

Machine learning (ML) allows computers to learn tasks directly from data.

This is the foundation for GenAI, LLMs, and Deep Learning.

It consists of two key phases 👇

Phase 1: Training

Training is where a model is learned through curated examples.

This consists of choosing parameters that minimize the discrepancy between our model’s predictions and reality.

Phase 2: Inference

Inference involves applying a model to new data to make predictions.

This could be predicting tomorrow’s temperature, detecting objects in an image, or generating landing page copy.


Stay tuned for tomorrow’s post, where I’ll discuss a special type of ML called Deep Learning (DL)...

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 2/5)

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 2/5)

But, how can computers develop a model of the world? 🤔

In traditional software, computers are given explicit instructions for doing a task.

In other words, human programmers use their intelligence to define rules and algorithms that computers can execute to produce a desired outcome.

Machine learning (ML), on the other hand, doesn’t work like this. Instead, it relies on a developer’s ability to curate high-quality examples from which the computer can learn.

This gives rise to 3 key ways computers can learn about the world 👇 

1. Machine Learning = programming computers with examples
2. Deep Learning = neural nets learn features and mappings from raw data
3. Reinforcement Learning = computers learn through trial and error


Stay tuned for tomorrow’s post, where I’ll discuss how ML works...

... or read you can the full blog post: https://lnkd.in/g7Ux7bSr

5 AI Projects You Can Build After Work 👇

5 AI Projects You Can Build After Work 👇 

Python is the native (programming) language of AI engineering. 
​
Yet, most newcomers to the field have never written a single line of it.
​
Here are 5 (beginner-friendly) projects you can build fast to develop your Python skills.
​
1) Automated Birthday Emailer
​
Create a .csv file containing the birthdays of your friends and family, and then write a simple Python script to email them on their birthdays automatically.
​
2) PDF Summarizer
​
Extract the text from a PDF using PyMuPDF, then summarize it using GPT-4o-mini using OpenAI's API.
​
3) Stock Price Visualizer
​
Use the yfinance library to download stock price data and visualize it using Plotly Dash.
​
Add features to the visualization, like selecting the ticker name and applying different moving average windows.
​
4) AI Job Board Scraper

Scrape your favorite job board using the requests and BeautifulSoup4 Python libraries
​
Bonus: Analyze the data to find the top-paying roles and skills using pandas.
​
5) Upwork Job Dashboard
​
Use Streamlit to build a custom dashboard to analyze Upwork job postings.
​

Let me know which one you want to build, and I'll share more resources and example code :)

25 AI Buzzwords Explained for Entrepreneurs 👇

25 AI Buzzwords Explained for Entrepreneurs 👇 

1) LLM = software that can perform arbitrary tasks via natural language
2) Prompt = the request you pass to an LLM
3) Prompt engineering = crafting your prompt to optimize task performance
4) Few-shot prompting = including task examples in your prompt
5) Context Window = the maximum amount of text an LLM can process
6) Hallucination = when LLMs make up things like facts and references
7) Guardrails = rules you apply to LLM inputs and outputs
8) Prompt Injection = when someone tricks your LLM into breaking your rules
9) Red Teaming = testing how well your LLM app follows your rules
10) Token = a unit of text that an LLM can understand
11) Temperature = controls the randomness of an LLM's response
12) RAG = automatically giving LLMs context to answer a specific question
13) Embedding = a collection of numbers representing a text's meaning 
14) Chunk = a snippet of text
15) Vector DB = a collection of chunks and their corresponding embeddings
16) Semantic Search = search based on a query's meaning, not keywords
17) AI Agent = an LLM system that can use tools to perform actions
18) Agentic AI = an LLM system with some level of agency
19) Function calling = an LLM's ability to use tools as needed
20) Fine-tuning = adapting a model to a specific use case via additional training
21) Distillation = using a bigger model to train a smaller (cheaper) one
22) Train-time compute = the cost of training an LLM
23) Test-time compute = the cost of using an LLM (after its trained)
24) Reinforcement Learning (RL) = a model's ability to learn via trial and error
25) RLHF = Aligning an LLM's response to human preferences via RL

👉 What's missing from this list?

--

While “MCP” might seem like yet another scary AI buzzword, it’s a simple idea.

While “MCP” might seem like yet another scary AI buzzword, it’s a simple idea.

MCP is a universal way to connect tools and context to AI apps...

It works via client-server architecture.

In other words, MCP clients send requests to MCP servers, which respond with access to tools, resources, and prompts.

This is just like when you (the client) go to a coffee shop and ask a barista (the server) for a pumpkin spice latte (the request), who eventually gives one to you (the response).

In a recent YouTube video, I talk more about how MCP works and walk through the implementation of an MCP server using Python.

👉 Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/dYf6diUD

10 AI Terms Explained in Plain English 👇

10 AI Terms Explained in Plain English 👇 

AI newcomers are welcomed to the field with a firehose of technical jargon.

However, you don’t need a PhD to wrap your head around AI.

I recently came across Greg Ceccarelli and Hamel H.'s amazing “Glossary of AI Terms” in language anyone can understand.

Here are a handful of my favorite definitions…

1) Agents = AI models that can perform tasks or run code without human help.
2) RAG = Providing relevant context to the LLM.
3) Vector DB = A special database for storing and searching embeddings.
4) Embeddings = Turning words into numbers that show meaning.
5) Hybrid Search = Combining search methods to get better results.
6) Reranking = Sorting results to pick the most important ones.
7) Fine-tuning = Adjusting a pre-trained model for a specific job.
8) RLHF = Training AI using people’s feedback.
9) Multimodal = Models that handle different data types like text and images.
10) Prompt Injection = A security risk where bad instructions are added to prompts.

👉 Link to complete list: https://lnkd.in/gF3DZg9Y

AI Roadmap for Entrepreneurs 👇

AI Roadmap for Entrepreneurs 👇 

The 5 things you need to know to build your next AI app...

1) Use AI Tools

Moving fast means you make mistakes faster than your competition and ship something before you run out of runway.

Tools like ChatGPT, Claude, Cursor, etc., are the best way to do that when it comes to learning and building.

2) Prompt Engineering

Learning how to write effective prompts not only helps you use AI tools better but also allows you to build better LLM systems.

There are a few universal tips you should know (e.g., give details, use structure, give examples), as well as model-specific ones you can find from the particular model provider.

3) RAG

While prompting alone can take you far, it falls short when your solution relies on specialized or user-specific information.

Having a basic understanding of retrieval (i.e. search) and how you can use it to improve LLM responses is central.

4) Tool-use & AI agents

We often don’t just want LLMs to process information for us; we want them to solve our problems.

This is where endowing models with the ability to perform actions (through tool use) helps.

5) Fine-tuning

Some use cases require changing an LLM’s behavior significantly. If prompting and other workarounds are not enough, fine-tuning is a viable option.

Additionally, this allows you to build specialized models for your specific use case, which can come with significant cost savings.


What would you add to this list?

--

There are only 2 ways to get LLMs to do what you want.

There are only 2 ways to get LLMs to do what you want.

You can either tell it or teach it...

This gives rise to two fundamental levels of AI engineering.

Level 1: Adapting models with tools and context

This is what most engineers focus on, most of the time.

It involves things like prompt engineering, setting up retrieval systems, and giving models access to tools.

Level 2: Adapting models via additional training

This level is all about fine-tuning, which allows one to further customize a model’s behavior to a greater extent than prompting alone.

The general term for this is post-training, which encompasses any machine learning that happens after the pre-training phase.


How do you think about LLM development?

Intelligence is NOT just reserved for humans.

Intelligence is NOT just reserved for humans.

Computers are fast approaching on our tails... here's how 👇 

Sairam said it well: “Intelligence is about how well your model [of the world] matches reality, and how fast you can update it when it doesn’t.”

Here are 4 ways computers can acquire and update world models 🌎 

1) Expert systems = people accumulate experience and data, and synthesize it into a computer program

2) Machine learning = people accumulate experience and data, and synthesize them into "features" from which computers can learn.

3) Deep learning = people accumulate data from which computers can learn.

4) Reinforcement learning = computers are directly given access to the world, so they can learn from it.


How else can computers gain intelligence?

Building a software product is easier than ever.

Building a software product is easier than ever.

But there’s a hidden cost to this…

Having an LLM code your entire application helps you move fast, but will incur technical debt.

Like financial debt, technical debt involves getting some benefit now (e.g., a finished app) while delaying the cost until later (e.g., learning how it works).

The other extreme is to code your app completely from scratch and only using the Python docs.

If you do this, you’ll understand every nook and cranny of your code base, but it will take you much longer 😅 

Therefore, an important skill developers must learn today is understanding how much technical debt to take on for a specific situation.

If speed now is the top priority, then more debt can be good.

If time later is more important, then less debt is better.


👉 How do you decide how much technical debt to take on?

6 patterns for automating workflows with LLMs 🤖

6 patterns for automating workflows with LLMs 🤖

A workflow is a series of steps that produce a desired outcome.

While we can go far with computer code in automating workflows, LLMs give us another level of flexibility and capability.

Here are a handful of common design patterns according to Anthropic.

1) Chaining = a series of LLM-based steps
2) Routing = using an LLM to route inputs to different flows
3) Sectioning = performing multiple steps simultaneously to reduce latency
4) Voting = doing the same step many times in parallel to improve performance
5) Orchestrator-Workers = using an LLM to break down a task and decide which steps to execute.
6) LLM in a Loop = evaluating the output of an LLM and giving it feedback

Are you using any of these in your LLM systems?

What do you do when your RAG application plateaus?

What do you do when your RAG application plateaus?

Instead of using a bigger (and more expensive) model, try this.

Most RAG apps use vector search to match queries to knowledge base items based on semantic similarity.

A problem with this, however, is that just because a query and item are semantically similar, it doesn't necessarily mean the item is *helpful* in answering the user's request.

One way to solve this problem is through fine-tuning.

Fine-tuning an embedding model involves training it on pairs of questions and their appropriate answers. 

The key approach for doing this is contrastive learning, which teaches the model to distinguish between helpful and unhelpful results by minimizing the distance between relevant pair embeddings (while maximizing the distance between irrelevant pair embeddings).

I walk through a concrete example of this (with code) where I fine-tune an embedding model based on AI job posts.

👉 You can read the full blog post here: https://lnkd.in/g6ZtKVyc

Before you “vibe code” your next AI app… consider this.

Before you “vibe code” your next AI app… consider this.

With today’s powerful LLMs, almost all coding work can be offloaded to an AI.

While this helps developers move 5X faster, this speed comes at a cost.

Just like how taking a loan to launch a startup incurs financial debt, using an LLM to code your application incurs technical debt.

In other words, you trade speed today for work you must do later.

Technical debt (like financial debt) isn’t inherently bad for a business; in fact, it can be very beneficial when used appropriately and skillfully.

Here are the 2 key things I consider when deciding how to use LLMs to code.

1) My Experience

Vibe coding a binary classifier is much less risky for me than vibe coding a website with React.

That’s because I’ve trained dozens of classifiers before but never used React.

2) App Run Count

Vibe coding an ad hoc data dashboard has very little risk.

However, vibe coding a SaaS app that will be used thousands of times by users presents a high risk because each run is an opportunity for a bug to appear and wake you up at 3AM to fix it 😅


How do you think about LLM’s writing your code?

What makes AI agents different than chatbots?

What makes AI agents different than chatbots?

When I was doing AI projects for clients, the #1 request I received was to build a custom chatbot.

6-12 months after that, the pendulum swung in the other direction where companies had become disenchanted with the excitement of chatbot.

People might feel we are seeing this again today with AI agents… but I don’t think that’s the case.

There are two key differences between the chatbots of 2023 and today’s agentic systems.

1) Tool use

Getting LLMs to use tools is no longer a hacky thing. Today, we have models fine-tuned for tool use from leading labs that work well out of the box.

This means LLM systems can readily break out of their “imagination land” and interact with the real world to solve practical problems.

2) Test-time compute

Another key innovation is the discovery of test time compute scaling i.e. the more tokens a model generates, the better its response.

This opens the gate for models to solve complex problems by 1) thinking about it before responding or 2) being called recursively in a loop with helpful feedback.


👉 What do you think? Are agents just another over-hyped AI topic?

Avoid this mistake when building AI projects…

Avoid this mistake when building AI projects…

The number one reason AI projects fail is because people start with the question: “How can I use this new tech?”

While this is a fine way to learn a new tool, a better question to ask is: “What problem can I solve?”

Here are 5 AI project ideas you can build this weekend that take this problem-first approach…

1) Resume Optimizer (Beginner)

❌ Problem: Struggling to land a new job
✅ Solution: Pass your resume and desired job description to GPT-4o and have it rewrite it to highlight your most relevant experience. Use Python libs like markdown and weasyprint to export the output resume as a PDF.

2) Upwork Proposal Optimizer (Beginner)

❌ Problem: Struggling to get your first freelance client
✅ Solution: Have an LLM rewrite your proposal template based on the specific job posting by extracting key pain points and demonstrating how you can solve them based on your experience and portfolio.

3) Meeting Follow-up Writer (Intermediate)

❌ Problem: Meeting follow-up emails are tedious
✅ Solution: Transcribe a meeting recording using Whisper and have an LLM craft a follow-up email based on a template. Note: If you don’t have a standard follow-up template, you can also have an LLM write that.

4) Upwork Demand Analyzer (Intermediate)

❌ Problem: I don’t know what services to sell
✅ Solution: Search for jobs that match your skillset, then use a tool like “Instant Data Scraper” to extract the job posting as a .csv file. Next, use text embeddings to cluster jobs and identify areas with the greatest demand.

5) Agentic Email Assistant (Advanced)

❌ Problem: My inbox is a disaster
✅ Solution: Connect an LLM to your Gmail inbox and have it respond to (or delete) low-priority emails based on past examples in your mailbox

Which one of these do you want to build?

2) Employee → Entrepreneur mindset shift

3) Focus more.

The problem with “AI agents” is that no one seems to agree on what it means.

The problem with “AI agents” is that no one seems to agree on what it means.

Basically, anything involving automation or LLMs is at risk of being an AI agent.

This is partly because the term has evolved over the past 2 years.

Here are 3 distinct phases of “AI agents” I’ve noticed:

Phase 1: LLM + Tools

These were the first types of systems I heard of called AI agents.

Agency comes in because we can give LLMs tools like API calls and search for interacting with the world in a self-directed way.

Phase 2: LLM Workflows

This is the most common definition I see these days.

The idea is to define workflows that involve LLMs as nodes and decision-makers to perform complex tasks.

Phase 3: End-to-end RL Training

The latest iteration of agents are systems like OpenAI’s Operator, which are trained on end-to-end reinforcement learning.

They can handle open-ended tasks and interact with real-world systems without much supervision.


What are some other types of AI agents you’ve seen?

80% of people are NOT passionate about their job.

80% of people are NOT passionate about their job.

Here’s the mental checklist I used to quit my job (to become an entrepreneur).

1) I want to work for myself

No point in becoming self-employed if it’s not something you want for yourself.

2) I value freedom more than security

The uncertainty of entreprenuership is probably what holds most people back.

However, this uncertainty is the cost of freedom, which is a trade some are willing to make.

3) I value growth more than comfort

This was the central reason I quit my job. I felt I was getting to comfortable in my FT role.

While this might sound like a good thing, it often means you are leaving potential on the table.

4) Status (and other peoples’s opinions of me) aren’t more important to me than my goals

Humans are hard-wired to care about status, which is another major deterrent for aspiring entrepreneurs.

Lucky for me, I’ve sort of always been a weirdo, so I’m used to ignoring what people think of me :P

5) I had made money doing something that wasn’t a job (e.g. freelance and content creation)

What gave me the confidence to think I could survive on my own was that I had previously generated income doing freelance work and content creation.

This is why I think having a “side-hustle” is a critical prerequisite to quitting a job.

6) I have 1 year of runway in savings

Realistically, in the first 1-2 years of entrepreneurship you will work 2X and make 1/2 as much as your FT role.

Having runway gives you more time to build momentum and ultimately allows you to make bigger bets.

--
What’s on your checklist?

AI principles I know at 29, I wish I had known at 24.

AI principles I know at 29, I wish I had known at 24.

1) Don’t use AI

Although AI innovations have exciting implications across industries, that does NOT mean it is a cure-all for all business problems.

If you can solve it with a simpler solution (i.e. code) do that.

2) Focus on problems not tech

Principle 1 is key because in the real-world you don’t get bonus points for using AI.

You get bonus points for solving a problem in a better way than an existing solution.

3) Spend more time on data curation

It’s easy to focus entirely on models, hyperparameters, and fancy ML techniques.

However, none of these will save a bad dataset.

4) Data quality > Data quantity

More data doesn’t always mean better models.

A small number of bad examples can kill model performance.

5) Run experiments

Unlike traditional coding, the best design choices for an ML system cannot be known at the outset.

These must be discovered through (systematic) experimentation.

6) Build evals early

Model evals and monitoring tend to be treated as an afterthought (i.e. something you build when it's time to push to prod).

However, these are perhaps the most important part of the ML pipeline becuase they are what tell if your system actually solves the problem. 

7) Start small

Don’t over-engineer your initial prototype.

The goal isn’t to ship this to prod but rather to build something useful as quickly as possible.


What are some key principles you’d add here?

Every data professional is capable of making $200,000/year as a freelancer.

Every data professional is capable of making $200,000/year as a freelancer.

Sadly, most people focus on the wrong skills...

Here are the 5 biggest mistakes I made at the start of my entrepreneurship journey.

1) Prioritizing hard skills over soft skills

What often distinguishes individual contributors is their technical prowess.

However, this is insufficient when working as a freelancer, because much of the work is figuring out what problem to solve.

This isn’t something you can figure out using Python or SQL, but rather by talking to your customer.

2) Marketing my skills rather than solutions to customer pain points

When I was freelancing, my Upwork profile beautifully laid out all my technical skills and “impressive” training.

The trouble is that clients don’t care about your skills compared to how much they care about their problems.

Your portfolio isn’t for you to comprehensively list your experience. It’s to attract the right customer.

3) Spending zero time on understanding my customer

To be fair, my messaging was so vague because I didn’t know who my customer was.

This resulted in a wide range of inquiries from customers across industries, which meant I was starting from zero at the beginning of every new client engagement.

Clarifying WHO you want to sell to not only helps avoid this learning curve but allows you to optimize your marketing for your customer.

4) Having an unclear offer

Another big mistake I made was offering “data science and AI services” (whatever that means).

In other words, it wasn’t clear what value I was providing my customer.

A better offer would be something like “I help startups build AI features that make them money”

5) Pricing for time (not value)

However, the biggest killer of an unclear offer was that I left money on the table.

I was stuck in the mindset of “I’m a data scientist for hire” with an hourly rate.

In contrast, if I had focused on solving problems for a particular customer, I could price for the value I generated for them.

This is an entirely different ballgame because I am no longer capped by my (limited) time, but rather by scale of my customer’s problems.

What are some key mistakes you've made on your journey?

Here’s how OpenAI turned an "internet document predictor" (i.e. GPT-3) into a helpful chatbot (i.e. ChatGPT).

Here’s how OpenAI turned an "internet document predictor" (i.e. GPT-3) into a helpful chatbot (i.e. ChatGPT).

In 2022, OpenAI published InstructGPT, a fine-tuned version of GPT-3 which was trained to be an intuitive and human-friendly AI assistant.

This consisted of two steps in the post-training process.

🪛 Step 1: Supervised Fine-tuning

GPT-3 was trained on (user input, response) pairs to teach it to have dialogue with a user (instead of generating internet documents).

However, this wasn't enough to make the responses maximally helpful and harmless. So they did another round of fine-tuning using reinforcement learning.

🪛 Step 2: Reinforcement Learning with Human Feedback (RLHF)

RLHF consisted of aligning InstructGPT's responses with human preferences.

The secret to the success of this step was the use of preference ranking examples which provided a high-quality training signal to improve model responses.

If you are curious about how RLHF works under the hood, I just posted a YouTube video about it and its more efficient reformulation, DPO.

Vector DBs and embeddings have become common in modern AI stacks.

Vector DBs and embeddings have become common in modern AI stacks. 

But where do embeddings come from?

To recap, an embedding is a (meaningful) vector representation of an object (e.g. text, images, audio, etc.), commonly used for feature extraction and RAG.

The central technique for creating useful embedding models is contrastive learning, a ML approach which seeks to represent different views of the same information similarly.

This works by curating a dataset of positive and negative pairs e.g. a query and a helpful response (positive) + a query and an unhelpful response (negative)

Contrastive learning then updates model parameters such that positive pairs become more similar while negative pairs become more dissimilar.

I recently used contrastive learning to fine-tune an embeddings model to better match resumes to AI job descriptions.

Building a multimodal RAG system for my blog posts...

Building a multimodal RAG system for my blog posts...

Although improving LLMs with RAG unlocks several practical use cases, there are some situations where relevant information exists in non-text formats, e.g., images, videos, charts, and tables.

In such cases, we can go one step further and build multimodal RAG systems, AI systems capable of processing text and non-text data.

Here's a simple workflow I used for building such a system:

1) Chunk text from articles and store them in a .json file
2) Extract images from each article and store their file paths in a .json file
3) Compute embeddings for each chunk and image using CLIP
4) Define a query and compute its embedding
5) Compute the similarity between the query embedding and each chunk/image embedding
6) Construct a prompt to answer the query given the most similar chunks/images
7) Pass prompt to Llama 3.2 Vision
8) Bonus: Build a chat UI

I implemented this project and walked through the example code in a YouTube video 👇

Although LLMs can perform a wide range of tasks out of the box, refining their responses based on human preferences can be challenging.

Although LLMs can perform a wide range of tasks out of the box, refining their responses based on human preferences can be challenging.

The trouble is that sometimes we don't know WHY we like one response vs another, making prompt engineering ineffective.

Alternatively, supervised fine-tuning requires manually curating ideal input-output pairs, which is time-consuming and may lack sufficient coverage.

This is where preference alignment techniques like Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) and Direct Policy Optimization (DPO) are helpful.

These instead rely on relative human preferences (i.e., ranking responses from best to worst), which are much easier for us to create.

In my latest blog post, I discuss both approaches and then use DPO to fine-tune Qwen2.5-0.5B to write YouTube titles based on my preferences.

Here's why DeepSeek-R1 is important (without the hype).

Here's why DeepSeek-R1 is important (without the hype).

Although this model caused its fair share of pandemonium, its central contribution was exposing the secrets behind reasoning models like o1.

i.e. how LLMs can "learn to reason" through reinforcement learning (RL).

The promise of RL is that models can learn by trial and error rather than being given explicit, human-generated examples.

This not only removes training data bottlenecks but also unlocks novel reasoning strategies that models can learn on their own.

I talk more about the technical details of o1 and DeepSeek-R1 in a recent YouTube video.

Corporate vs Freelance Data Science… My Honest Reflections.

Corporate vs Freelance Data Science… My Honest Reflections.

As someone who has worked as a data scientist at a company and independently, here is how I’d compare the two.

Income 💸 

While the average income is probably about the same, the key difference is the income distribution. 

Corporate salaries are more normally distributed, while freelance income is more fat-tailed. In other words, you can make 2X your corporate salary as an independent, but also you can make 1/2 of it.

Freedom 🦅 

Freelancing has a corporate beat on this one. 

As a freelancer, you have complete control over what projects you take on and when/where you work.

Uncertainty 😵‍💫 

Broadly speaking, corporate has freelancing beat on this one (especially in the early days). However, there’s a nuance here. 

Corporate gives a strong perception of stability, so when something eventually DOES go wrong, it can be devastating. 

While for freelance, instability is the norm, so freelancers become much more resilient toward it.

Learning 🤓 

Both settings have great learning opportunities. In my experience, however, these have different flavors. 

In corporate, learning can be optional given the coverage of other team members and lean more toward technical skills. 

On the other hand, freelance can be very much ”learn or die,” which makes it more powerful, IMO.


How do you compare these two work environments?

I Fine-tuned FLUX.1 on My Face!

I Fine-tuned FLUX.1 on My Face! 

Here's how you can too...
​
Step 1: Curate Training Images
​
Gather 10-20 images of yourself in various settings from different angles. Crop these images so that they are 1024x1024 (using Python).
​
Step 2: Generate Captions
​
Use a visual language model (e.g. Llava 13B) to write captions for each photo automatically. Be sure to include a unique "trigger token" in each caption, which the model can learn to associate with your face.
​
Step 3: Fine-tune the Model
​
Upload a .zip file containing your image-caption pairs to this training endpoint via the Replicate API (or the web UI).
​
Step 4: Use the Model
​
After ~10 min and ~$1 for training, a model playground will spin up on Replicate, from which you can generate images from the model.

I walk through this whole process in a recent blog post.

🔗 Check it out: https://lnkd.in/giYp7VFx

AI Agents Are the New SaaS.

AI Agents Are the New SaaS.

Last week, I sat down with Aytekin Tank, who, over the past 20 years, has grown his SaaS company (Jotform) from 0 to 500+ employees.

He described an analogy that stuck with me between the "SaaS revolution" and what we see today with AI agents...

Back in 2004, people mainly interacted with software by downloading it directly onto their computers.

While this may sound benign, this little friction can be a killer to new software businesses (especially back when computers were slower than today).

Then came SaaS products (e.g. Gmail), which ran their product entirely in the browser. This streamlined user experience has become the standard we now take for granted.

However, there is still friction in SaaS UIs. Namely, learning a new app's UI still takes time and effort, no matter how hard product developers improve it.

This is where Aytekin says AI agents will create another revolution for software products.

Namely, LLMs can act as a human-software interface to make UIs simpler and more intuitive.

How do you see the future of AI agent products?

--

What are AI agents? (without the hype)...

What are AI agents? (without the hype)...

Although work around AI agents has been developing for the past year, it has more recently entered the public discourse around AI.

With this (naturally) comes a messy assortment of definitions of what the term “AI agent” actually means.

Here are a few definitions that I’m thinking about these days.

📌 OpenAI (Sam A): “AI systems that do work for you independently. You give them a task, and they go off and do it.” [1]

📌 Anthropic: Systems where LLMs dynamically direct their own processes and tool usage, maintaining control over how they accomplish tasks. [2]

📌 Hugging Face: A system that uses an LLM as its engine, and it has access to functions called tools. [3]

How do you define “AI agents”?

Multimodal RAG systems can retrieve and synthesize information from different data modalities (e.g. text and images)

Like text-only RAG, the retrieval step of these systems can be implemented using vector search (but with multimodal embeddings).

One issue with this approach, however, is that vector search results from a general-purpose embedding model may perform poorly in domain-specific use cases (just like in regular RAG).

In a recent blog post, I discussed how we can mitigate this issue via fine-tuning multimodal embedding models.

I made your LinkedIn content strategy for you (no matter where you’re at)

I made your LinkedIn content strategy for you (no matter where you’re at)

Last week, I chatted with 7 technical professionals and entrepreneurs struggling with content creation at various levels.

Here were some common patterns (and what I recommended)...

📌 Group 1: Never posted
🗺️ Strategy: Post once.

Common themes for this group were saying things like "I don't know what to post" or over-complicating the process.

The solution is simple... just post once. Share a blog post, a milestone, or a recent unlock. 

Feel free to steal formats from my profile :)

📌 Group 2: Posted, but not consistently
🗺️ Strategy: Pick a reasonable cadence (1-3x a week) and commit to it for 90 days.

At this point, it doesn't make sense to optimize because, one, you don't know what works yet. And two, writing is still effortful for you.

Keep doing it until it's easy!

📌 Group 3: Post consistently, but no traction
🗺️ Strategy: Find what works for you by...
- Keep posting!
- Do bi-weekly reviews of your top-performing content in the past 28 days
- Extract formats/topics that work for you
- Make more of those (while still experimenting)
Bonus: 2X your output to make progress faster


P.S. I fine-tuned FLUX.1 on my face... what do you think?

Recently, the conversation around AI development has focused on foundation models vs AI apps, but there is another key layer here.

Recently, the conversation around AI development has focused on foundation models vs AI apps, but there is another key layer here. 

AI labs like OpenAI, Anthropic, Mistral, and Deepseek build foundation models that can be adapted to a wide range of use cases. 

AI startups build on top of foundation models to solve real-world problems. 

However, this AI stack has room for another type of organization. 

This is what I call an "AI studio", which is focused exclusively on post-training i.e. model fine-tuning, distillation, and merging. 

Similar to an AI lab, these groups develop models that can be used in a wide range of applications (without requiring millions in funding) 

Similar to an AI startup, these groups can be small and scrappy, with a focus on solving real-world problems. 

The more I think about it, the more I want to start one of these “AI studios” 🤔 

What do you think?

3 Ways to Fine-Tune an AI Model 👇

3 Ways to Fine-Tune an AI Model 👇 

Fine-tuning involves adapting a model to a particular use case through additional training.

Before doing this, however, we must ask ourselves a fundamental question: which parameters do I want to fine-tune?

While there are countless ways to do this, I like to split them into 3 buckets.

Bucket 1: All Parameters 🌎 

The simplest approach is to retrain all the parameters in your base model, also called full parameter fine-tuning.

This works well when you have a lot of data and want to make fundamental changes to the model’s behavior. 

The downside, of course, is that this is the most computationally expensive option and risks the model “forgetting” key abilities.

Bucket 2: Some Parameters 🪛 

To mitigate the compute requirements and training risks of full fine-tuning, one can pick a subset of parameters to retrain. This is called transfer learning, which typically consists of retraining the last few layers of a model (and maybe adding a new one).

The key upside of this is that you can significantly improve a model's performance on a novel task without major data and compute costs. 

However, even this approach can be impractical for very large base models.

Bucket 3: New Parameters (i.e. adapters) 💻 

This final bucket consists of adding a (relatively) small number of trainable parameters to key parts of a model while keeping its original parameters frozen. The technical term for this approach is Parameter Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT).

A popular PEFT approach is Low-Rank Adaption (LoRA), which has made fine-tuning large language models practical for GPU-poor practitioners. 

Additionally, this is a handy approach when working with a relatively small training data set (which is the biggest unlock IMO).

Q: How do I handle large docs that exceed an LLM’s context limit?

Q: How do I handle large docs that exceed an LLM’s context limit?

A: RAG (i.e. Retrieval Augmented Generation)

RAG has emerged as a central technique for building LLM-based systems.

Here's the basic idea: take your doc(s), split it (them) into chunks, and automatically retrieve the most relevant ones at inference.

Given the wide range of queries people will type into LLM systems, this retrieval is typically facilitated (at least in part) by text embeddings.

Here's how that works...

Step 1: Compute vector representations (i.e. embeddings) for chunks (before inference time)

Step 2: Translate input query into a vector representation (at inference time)

Step 3: Compute the similarity between the input text vector and each item in the vector DB. Return the most similar items.

Drop your RAG questions 👇

Vector search visually explained...

Vector search visually explained...

In contrast to keyword-based search, we can use text embeddings to implement search based on the meaning of a user’s query... rather than the particular words or phrases used.

Here is a simple example for searching over AI job candidate resumes.

Step 1: translate resumes to vectors using a text embedding model
Step 2: translate a query, e.g., "I need someone to help me build my data infrastructure," into a vector (using the same embedding model).
Step 3: compute the similarity between the query and each resume vector
Step 4: return the most similar resumes as search results

The figure below shows what the search looks like visually... 

You can see various resumes colored by job title plotted as dots and the query plotted as a black star.

The query ("I need someone to help me build my data infrastructure") is colocated to the "Data Engineering" resumes colored in blue.

This is appropriate since a data engineer is likely the person you want to hire for this job.

AMA about this example or vector-based search :)

Data Science was hard until I learned these 5 things…

Data Science was hard until I learned these 5 things… 
👇 

1) Python 

Programming is essential for any data scientist because it is the only reasonable way to work with large volumes of data (sorry, Excel). 

It has the added benefit of a rich open-source ecosystem where there’s a library for basically any task you want to do 

2) Vector Spaces 

Data organized in rows and columns can be thought of as a high-dimensional point cloud, where each dimension corresponds to a feature in your data. 

This is probably my most common mental picture when thinking about data science tasks. 

3) Optimization 

On the surface, machine learning looks like magic. Under the hood, however, is the process of minimizing a loss function. 

Learning the “standard of continuous optimization problems” (while scary sounding) gave me tremendous clarity about model training. 

4) Distributions 

When I first got into data science, I tended to think of things as point estimates, e.g., what’s tomorrow’s temperature? 

However, this is a narrow way of thinking. What I’ve found more helpful is thinking in distributions, e.g., what does tomorrow’s temperature distribution look like? 

5) Expectation Values 

Probabilities don’t tell you the whole story. The potential upside and downside of each possibility matter.

For example, if a product has a 10% chance of failure, it can still make sense to pursue it if the potential upside is huge and the downside is small.

This quarter, I am doubling down on building products.

This quarter, I am doubling down on building products.

While I'm still a total noob, here are the 5 key principles guiding my product development...

​1) Optimize for speed (move fast)

​As a recovering technical person, my favorite part of building is experimenting with new tools and technologies.

​While this is a lot of fun, it can lead to over-sophisticated products, which crumble when deployed into the wild. Speed allows me to iterate faster and get more shots on goal.

2) Moving fast ≠ rushing

The key point here is using speed as a forcing function for simplicity (i.e. "moving fast").

Rather than asking, "Can I get it done?" asking... "How could I get it done?

​3) Ship monthly

​To make principles 1 and 2 concrete, I'll be time-boxing my development window to just 1 month.

​This gives a clear constraint to drive creativity and action.

​4) Problems are a good thing

​One hesitation for aggressive timelines is worrying about something breaking.

​But this isn't helpful for two reasons... 1) if something breaks, that means people are actually using the product, and 2) every problem (once resolved) leads to a better product.

​5) Solve your own problems

​Product development is about two things: pain points and customers.

​To simplify this for myself, I'm going to focus on my own pain points (thus, pain points for people like me).

This not only allows me to move faster, but if the product fails, I can still get value from it personally :)

5 Resume Myths That Kept Me Unemployed 👇

5 Resume Myths That Kept Me Unemployed 👇


1) "More is better

My biggest mistake was trying to fit every bit of potentially relevant experience into my resume to make me sound more "qualified".

When it comes to resumes, however, you've only got 7 seconds of someone's attention, so the best strategy is to include only 2 to 3 key points most relevant to the role. (You can talk about your other experiences in the interview.)

2) "I don't need to tailor my resume

For a while, I had a single resume that summarized all my work experience.

While this was easy for me, it resulted in a lot of irrelevant points, which made me a less compelling candidate (and jobless).

3) "I need an objective statement

Objective statements are common in resume templates.

In my experience, however, the main thing an objective statement accomplishes is "using up" a hiring manager's precious attention on low-value information.

4) "Writing down my experience is enough

While skills and experience are the most important part of getting a job, simply writing them down is not enough.

How you convey your experience matters. My rule of thumb is to put the important stuff near the top and the less important stuff near the bottom (and remove the unimportant stuff altogether)

5) "I don't need a portfolio

It took me 1 year (of procrastination) to make my portfolio website.

However, this was one of the two main reasons I got my job at Toyota.

With free no-code tools like GitHub Pages, there's no good reason not to have a portfolio (unless you like being unemployed). 
Here's a tutorial on that: https://lnkd.in/gBrMmXmE

Python was hard until I learned these 5 things 👇

Python was hard until I learned these 5 things 👇 


1. Google things generously

Most errors were solved 5+ years ago on some StackOverflow forum, which can be found by Googling the error message.

2. Use libraries

Anytime I want to use a data science or ML method, I first find the libraries that already implemented it. Even if I don't use it, their docs are a good resource for learning.

3. Jupyter Notebooks for experimentation

The seed of almost all my coding projects is a Jupyter Notebook. This is because they enable me to experiment and iterate quickly.

4. help() and dir()

It took me way too long to learn about these functions. help() prints the doc for any variable's class, and dir() prints its attributes.

5. Learn by building projects

While textbooks and lectures are a great way to learn the fundamentals, so much of programming knowledge can only come from practical expertise.

Bonus: use ChatGPT/Claude as a coding assistant and tutor

5 things I had to un-learn to go from Data Scientist → Entrepreneur 👇

5 things I had to un-learn to go from Data Scientist → Entrepreneur 👇 

1) Progress = learning more tech skills 

Going from a good to a great coder won’t move the needle as much as going from bad to mediocre in key non-tech skills (i.e., sales, marketing, writing, customer calls, etc.) 

2) Building for “prod” with 0 users 

When working at an established company, ML projects might immediately impact thousands of customers and millions of dollars, so you have to build for scale from the start. 

However, as an entrepreneur, you’re more often seeking validation, which means speed and iteration are much more important than scalability. 

3) Building (rather than buying) just because I can 

Before, I had a tendency to avoid paid software tools/services when I felt I could implement them myself. 

Now, I bias toward paying for solutions that can help me move faster. 

4) You’re done when you deploy 

As a data scientist, once the project was built and deployed, I could relax. 

As an entrepreneur, this is only the start. After deploying, I need to let people know about it and (hopefully) pay for it. 

5) Seek sophistication 

Data science has endless interesting technical ideas that can applied to endless applications. Exploring these is fun and a big reason why I love data science. 

However, as an entrepreneur, I must fight this urge and instead bias toward simple techniques and solutions.

Embeddings are a central concept in machine learning.

Embeddings are a central concept in machine learning. 

They are vector representations of data (e.g. text and images) which are helpful in performing downstream tasks. 

While text and images look very different, this shared mathematical representation makes it possible to directly compare the two! 

This is the idea behind multimodal embeddings, which represent multiple data modalities in the same vector space such that similar concepts are co-located (independent of their original representations). 

For example, the picture of a cute cat and its corresponding caption will be relatively close in the vector space. 

This unlocks use cases such as 0-shot image classification and embedding-based image search. 

I show how we can apply multimodal embeddings to these two use cases in a recent YouTube video: https://lnkd.in/g52xxWZ2

Multimodal RAG systems process knowledge stored in text and non-text data.

Multimodal RAG systems process knowledge stored in text and non-text data. 

While there are countless ways to build such a system, here are 3 key elements. 

1) Context retrieval system = uses input query to automatically retrieve relevant information stored in text (or non-text) formats 

2) Prompt template = organizes input query and retrieved context so that the downstream model generates helpful responses 

3) Multimodal LLM = model that can process text and non-text data

Last month, I booked my most expensive mentorship call yet at $700/hr 😬

Last month, I booked my most expensive mentorship call yet at $700/hr 😬

While this might sound like a big number, the person on the other side of the call makes $100k/mo as a solo AI entrepreneur.

Here are my key takeaways from this conversation...

1) Focus on customer pain points and problems, not your past experience and skills.
2) Price for the customer's value, not your time.
3) The bigger the price tag, the longer the copy (i.e. delay the ask)
4) Get hyper-clear on the customer and their problem, then attract them with free content (on socials) and a lead magnet.
5) The difference between 10k/mo and 100k/mo is more often business strategy rather than technical expertise.

Although these points might be Business 101 for some, many technical founders (like me) never learned these basics.

This is great news because it means I can probably get significant gains from a few simple adjustments.

Super grateful to Jason Liu for taking the time to share his wisdom with me 🙏

Text embeddings have become widespread with the popularity of RAG.

Text embeddings have become widespread with the popularity of RAG. 

But.. how can we extend these systems to include non-text data? 

Over the past year, we’ve seen a rise in multimodal models, like GPT-4o, which are capable of natively processing text, images, and audio. 

While these models unlock many use cases, conventional RAG systems relying on text-only knowledge search can only partially utilize this capability. 

One way to overcome this limitation are multimodal embeddings, which represent both text and non-text data in the same vector space. 

In my latest YouTube video, I discuss how these embeddings are developed and two example use cases: 0-shot classification and image search.

AI seems to be riddled with buzzwords these days.

AI seems to be riddled with buzzwords these days.

Here are 10 common AI terms every practitioner should know...

1) RAG = automatically providing relevant context (i.e. docs) to an AI system so it can generate better responses

2) Vector DB = numerical representations of documents which can be used for RAG and search

3) Fine-tuning = adapting a model to a particular use case through additional training

4) AI Agent = an AI system that can plan and execute tasks

5) Evals = tests that score an AI system’s efficacy

6) Hallucination = a "made-up" response from an AI that sounds reasonable

7) Multimodal = data of different formats (e.g. text, images, audio, videos, tables, time series)

8) Small Language Models = LLMs with ~1B parameters

9) Quantization = reducing the precision of model parameters to reduce its size

10) Distillation = using a large model to train a smaller one

--
What's missing from this list?

The best way to learn Python (IMO) is by doing projects.

The best way to learn Python (IMO) is by doing projects. 

However, those getting started often struggle with generating project ideas. 

Here are 5 Python project ideas that you can build this weekend… 

1. Automated Birthday Message Emailer (Beginner) 

Remembering people’s birthdays (let alone telling them “Happy Bday”) can be a struggle. 

Create a .csv file containing the names and birthdays of people you like, and automatically email them a bday message when the day comes. 

2. Arxiv AI Paper Retriever (Beginner) AI research has exploded over the past few years, with thousands of papers being submitted a month. 

Build a tool that automatically downloads any paper uploaded to [cs.AI] on Arxiv and filters them based on keywords. 

3. Resume Matcher (Intermediate) 

A common struggle for recruiters and job seekers is finding roles that are a good fit based on skills and experience. 

While there are many ways to do this, an interesting approach is using text embeddings of resumes and job descriptions and matching them based on similarity. 

4. Automated DocString Writer (Intermediate) 

One of the more tedious (yet important) parts of programming is writing docstrings from custom functions. 

Today, this can be effectively automated using GPT-4o-mini (or any other LLM) via Openai’s API. 

5. YouTube Video to Blog Converter (Advanced) 

A time-consuming part of being a creator is refactoring content for different modalities. 

Something that can help with this is translating YouTube videos into blog posts based on the video’s transcript using your favorite LLM. 

--
s/o to Mathew Olajide, Fahad Ebrahim, and Saijai Osika for ideas 1-3, respectively 😁 

Let me know if you want me to flesh any of these out in the comments 👇

Here is (entrepreneurship) advice I wish someone told me sooner…

Here is (entrepreneurship) advice I wish someone told me sooner… 

💡 Sell first, don’t build. 

In other words, if you have an idea for a product or service, DO NOT jump into developing it; instead, try to get customers for it. 

This is important because there is no point in developing an idea that no one is willing to pay for (i.e. doesn’t solve a problem). 

Focusing on customer acquisition first allows you to 1) validate your idea and 2) align product development with customer needs. 

This is exactly what I did when launching the AI Builders Bootcamp...

I didn’t start by creating all the course material (which would have taken weeks). Rather, I simply built a landing page (which took an afternoon). 

Then, I tweaked the landing page until I found something people were interested in (i.e., waitlist sign-ups crossed 200). 

With this kind of positive signal, building the course became much easier because 1) I was very motivated to make it good, and 2) I could get direct feedback from customers. 

A huge thanks to Santiago, who shared this insight of “building the landing page first” a few months back 🙏

Over the past year, we’ve seen LLMs gain the ability to see (i.e. process images) and hear (i.e. process audio directly), but how does that work under the hood?

Over the past year, we’ve seen LLMs gain the ability to see (i.e. process images) and hear (i.e. process audio directly), but how does that work under the hood? 

Here are 3 general ways to do that 👇

1. LLM + Tools: Augment LLMs with pre-built components 

2. LLM + Adapters: Augment LLMs with multi-modal encoders or decoders, which are aligned via adapter fine-tuning 

3. Unified Models: Expand LLM architecture to fuse modalities at pre-training 

In my latest blog post in Towards Data Science, I discuss these three approaches and share example code for (locally) using LLaMA 3.2 Vision to perform various image-to-text tasks.

Software 3.0 = Repurposing general-purpose ML models for specific use cases (i.e. GenAI + Foundation Models)

But… what’s Software 4.0 going to be? 🤔

Getting a Data Science job was hard until I did these 5 things 👇

Getting a Data Science job was hard until I did these 5 things 👇 

1) Focused my resume: removed details and skills that were irrelevant to a data science job description 

2) Real-world projects: joined a university research group and started taking freelance gigs on Upwork. 

3) Made a portfolio: it doesn’t matter how great your past projects were if no one knows about them. Making a website portfolio is an easy way to showcase your skills and stand out. 

4) Stayed out of the weeds: a big mistake I made in early job interviews was diving into technical details when discussing projects. A better approach is to give a high-level story and go into detail if people ask. 

5) Be yourself: this way, you can get a realistic sense of whether the role is a good fit.

Learning from those ahead of me has been one of the greatest "hacks" for accelerating my entrepreneurial journey.

Learning from those ahead of me has been one of the greatest "hacks" for accelerating my entrepreneurial journey.

While many will preach the importance of a mentor, it's not always clear how to find one...

Here are 3 things that helped me go from being mentorless to mentor-rich 👇 

1) Changed my definition of "mentor

My initial notion of mentorship was a formal relationship consisting of weekly calls during which I'd get advice and feedback on all aspects of my journey.

But that's rarely the case...

Instead, mentorship is typically informal and happens organically over time.
This might consist of sporadic coffee chats, Zoom calls, or just DM convos on LinkedIn. Additionally, having a single mentor for all matters is unlikely. No one has walked the same unique path as you. That's why learning from different people for different topics is often necessary.

2) Paying people for their time

Good mentors are busy and usually don't have time to do coffee chats with strangers on the internet.

A simple hack I've found to bypass this is directly booking time with people 1-2 steps ahead of me. I've done this several times with data science freelancers on Upwork.

3) Growing my personal brand

Another way to make it easier for mentors to talk to you is to be less of a stranger.

This is where having a personal brand has helped me. I've done this by sharing YouTube, Medium, and LinkedIn content.

Now, people I'd consider mentors have even contacted me for coffee chats!

AI has changed a lot since I started 5 years ago.

AI has changed a lot since I started 5 years ago. 

Here’s how I’d learn it if I had to start over… 

1. Learn Python 

Although some say you don’t need to learn to code anymore, I still think it’s essential for anyone who wants to build custom software solutions. 

2. Build Projects 

The AI space is too massive and evolving too quickly to effectively learn from a textbook. The best approach (IMO) is to start by building projects and learning concepts as needed. 

3. Start with Kaggle/HF Datasets 

While you’ll never find neatly curated data in the real world, I think using resources like Kaggle or Hugging Face is a great starting place for beginners. 

Some libraries worth learning for this initial project are: Pandas (or Polars), matplotlib, and sklearn 

4. Find a real-world project 

After one or two toy projects, it’s time to start working on something more practical. The best projects solve a real-world problem. 

I’d seek one out by reaching out to businesses or other orgs in my network to see if I could offer them free work. 

5. Use ChatGPT and Cursor 

AI coding assistants have become the norm for programming. Use them to help you learn faster and get you unblocked as needed.

Last year, I passed on a $150k data science promotion to pursue my entrepreneurial dream life.

Last year, I passed on a $150k data science promotion to pursue my entrepreneurial dream life.

Here’s my honest advice for data people considering a similar transition 👇 

1) Start with a side hustle 

Making money as an entrepreneur is very different than getting a paycheck. 

A side hustle is a great, low-stakes way to develop the necessary skillset.

The way I got started was through content creation and freelancing. 

2) Learn how to sell 

Data people typically have high-value skills like programming, data analytics, and machine learning. 

However, having these skills is not sufficient for monetizing them. 

For that, you need to figure out how to sell yourself and your offers. 

3) Shift your mindset from “What job can I do?” to “What problems can I solve?” 

This is one of the biggest mindset shifts I’ve had to make this past year. 

Focusing on fulfilling a role means you will always need someone's permission to get paid (whether a manager or a client). 

However, when you focus on solving problems, there are very few constraints on how you can generate value, so you can make a living on your terms.

This idea from Physics is gaining popularity in AI.

This idea from Physics is gaining popularity in AI.

It's a concept called "quantization".

While this might sound like a scary and sophisticated word, it's a simple idea. 

When you hear “quantizing,” think of splitting a range of numbers into buckets. 

For example, there are infinite possible numbers between 0 and 100 

Like... 1, 27, 55.3, 83.7823, and so on 

We could quantize this range by splitting it into buckets of whole numbers. 

In other words, 1, 27, 55, 83 

We could even go one step further and split it into bigger buckets following factors of 10.

E.g 0, 20, 50, and 80 

While quantization is used in Physics, music production, and beyond, it’s recently gained popularity in AI.

This is because it allows us to take massive AI models and shrink their computational requirements by quantizing a model's parameters.

Getting a Data Science Job was hard until I learned these 5 things 👇

Getting a Data Science Job was hard until I learned these 5 things 👇  

1. Adapt your resume to the specific role

You have about 7 seconds of a hiring manager's attention when reviewing your resume; use it to call out all the skills they listed in the job description.

2. Do real-world projects

While toy projects from class or Kaggle are a great way to learn, hiring managers care about real-world impact.

3. Make a portfolio 

Despite the free no-code tools for making a portfolio website, most people don't make one. That makes this a super easy way to stand out.

4. Stay out of the weeds (unless they ask) 

This was one of my greatest struggles. When someone asked about a project, I would dive right into the technical details. This is the best way to lose someone's attention (even data scientists).

5. Be yourself (not who you think they want to hire)

When I interviewed for my full-time data science role, I dove into a rant about my love for optimization. Most people get confused and awkward when I discuss such topics, but not the interviewers. They got pumped up... that's when I knew I found my people 😁 

What was an unlock for you when applying to data science roles?

The first question to ask when starting a data science or ML project is not…

The first question to ask when starting a data science or ML project is not… 

What ML method should I use? 
How should I prepare the data? 
Or even… where will I get the data? 

Instead, one should ask—"Are the data thin-tailed or fat-tailed?

Thin-tailed data are Gaussian-like things 🔔

This means there’s a typical value the data is spread around and plays nicely with all our statistical and ML tools. 

Fat-tailed data are more Pareto-like (i.e. the 80-20 rule) 💸

The key property of fat-tailed data is that the minority of the observations drive the aggregate statistics. 

A critical consequence is that fat-tailed data do not play nicely with our favorite statistical measures or modeling techniques. 

This is why predicting things like future sales, stock prices, and pandemic deaths is (very) challenging)…

The excitement (and fear) surrounding AI boils down to one thing — automation.

The excitement (and fear) surrounding AI boils down to one thing — automation. 

While we might think that more automation means more efficiency, it can often be the exact opposite. 

This was a painful lesson Elon Musk learned during Tesla’s Model 3 launch, which led him to develop a 5-step algorithm for solving engineering problems. 

Here’s a breakdown… 

📌 Step 1: Question Requirements 

Requirements are the constraints one must work within for a project, and more often than not, some are more negotiable than others. 

The goal is to make the requirements less dumb. Musk employs two critical questions to do this. One, why is that required? And two, who created that requirement? (Like specifically someone’s name) 

📌 Step 2: Delete 

With the requirements a little less dumb, one can begin designing and building the AI system. 

During this process, there will inevitably be components that, despite careful consideration, turn out to be unnecessary when put into the real world. 

As Musk says, “The best part is no part.” In other words, if a step or module in the system can be removed, then it should be. 

📌 Step 3: Simplify or Optimize 

Deletion helps distill a system to its key components, but there is often more room for improvement. 

For example, the current design may use a large language model to identify a candidate’s highest level of education or specific keywords. 

However, this could be replaced with a (much) simpler keyword search over the candidate’s resume. 

📌 Step 4: Accelerate 

At this point, we should have a lean and efficient system. The next question to ask ourselves is, “How can we move faster?” 

For example, if building an AI tool for the HR team, the bottleneck might be slow communication between the recruiter and hiring manager, a lack of user proficiency in the application, or insufficient recruiting staff. 

📌 Step 5: Automate 

It’s important to do this step last because automation begets scaling. While this might sound like a good thing, scaling a flawed process can be a complete nightmare. 

Put another way, automation scales not only outputs but also errors. 

-- 
I discuss this more in a recent blog post in The Data Entrepreneurs Medium publication. 

👉 Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/gepXD4Gg

While bigger ML models come with performance gains, they also come with greater challenges in deployment.

While bigger ML models come with performance gains, they also come with greater challenges in deployment.

This is where "Knowledge Distillation" can help.

The idea is to use a large “teacher” model to train a smaller “student” model. 

A simple way to do this is to generate synthetic data from a teacher model and train the student model on it. 

This is exactly what Stanford researchers did in their Alpaca model, which learned to respond to user prompts like ChatGPT. 

A more powerful but sophisticated way of doing this is training on the teacher model’s logits. 

This provides a richer learning signal to the student model than just a simple True-False label. 

If you want to learn more about knowledge distillation, I share a code example in a recent Towards Data Science blog post 👇 

https://lnkd.in/gzFdnE4a

This allows us to take massive AI models and shrink their computational requirements by quantizing model parameters. 

While “quantization” might sound scary and sophisticated, it is a simple idea. 

When you hear it, just think—"splitting a range of numbers into buckets” 

For example, infinite possible numbers exist between 0 and 100, e.g. 1, 27, 55.3, 83.7823, and so on. 

We could quantize this range by splitting it into buckets of whole numbers, i.e. 1, 27, 55, 83.

Or even split into buckets of factors of 10: 0, 20, 50, 80.

I talk more about quantization (and other LLM compression techniques) in a recent YouTube video.

👉 Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/gqE3Gxv7

There is a famous equation for success: Skill + Luck = Success

There is a famous equation for success: Skill + Luck = Success 

However, I’ve recently reformulated it for myself. 

Skills come from experience i.e. Skill = Reps + Time 

Luck, on the other hand, may sound like something that falls from the sky, but we have more influence on it than we think. 

Luck comes to those who put themselves out there (i.e. if you don’t show up, you can’t get lucky). 

Another part is that if you stick around long enough, you’ll eventually get lucky. 

Bring these together we see that: Luck = Reps (showing up) + Time (sticking around) 

Therefore, the equation to success becomes quite simple. 

2 x (Reps + Time) = Success 

👉 In other words, take the number of reps and the amount of time you think it’ll take and then multiply it by two. 

That’s what will lead to success.

Statistics is fundamental to data science, but that’s not all it’s good for.

Statistics is fundamental to data science, but that’s not all it’s good for. 

Here are 3 statistics principles that improved my decision-making 👇  

1) Expectations Values 🤔 

When weighing outcomes, it’s not just about the probability of success but also the potential upside and downside of each. 

Even if something has a low probability of success, it can still be the right call if it has a huge upside and little downside. 

2) Population Thinking 🧠 

While summary metrics (e.g., mean, standard deviation, and accuracy) are widely used in business, they don’t tell the whole story. 

Behind every summary is a wide range of possibilities (i.e. a distribution). Remembering this is important.

3) “All models are wrong (some are useful)” ❌ 

We all have internal models of the world that we use to make decisions. 

Never questioning these models keeps people stuck and leads to poor decision-making.

The 1st plot below shows business survival rates est in 1994 up until 2023

12 years ago, “Data Scientist” was the sexiest job of the century.

12 years ago, “Data Scientist” was the sexiest job of the century. 

Today, it’s still an in-demand role, offering cushy salaries… 

But what do they actually do? 

In my view, the main job of a data scientist is to answer questions using data. 

This consists of 4 key activities 👇 

1) Have a question to answer—this typically comes from clients and business stakeholders.

2) Acquiring the relevant data—this is the boring yet most important part.

3) Analyzing data—once the data are in a usable form, data scientists use tools like Python or R to compute statistics and create data visualizations. 

4) Build models—we can use data to construct predictive models to solve problems and support decision-making.

5 Negotiation tips for data freelancers

5 Negotiation tips for data freelancers

👇 

1) Rephrasing

Demonstrate understanding by restating the other side's point in your own words

2) Labels

Statements such as "It seems like you've given this a lot of thought" or "It sounds like you have a good reason for saying that" can help get information from a client more effectively than direct questions.

3) Calibrated questions

Questions like "How am I supposed to do that?" can help the other side put themselves in your shoes during a negotiation 

4) No-oriented questions

Rephrasing questions like "Do you want to hop on a short discovery call?" to "Would you be against hoping on a short discovery call?" 

5) Negotiate multiple terms simultaneously

Different sides value things differently. That's why negotiating multiple terms at once, i.e. price, duration, scope, can help you identify opportunities for value creation.

s/o to fellow Christopher Voss reader and practitioner 🚀 Jeremy ARANCIO

While one might think ChatGPT launched the era of AI chatbots, agents, assistants, etc., there is more to the story…

While one might think ChatGPT launched the era of AI chatbots, agents, assistants, etc., there is more to the story… 

”Traditional” ML relies on using (a lot of) data to create software systems that no human could code. 

However, ChatGPT demonstrated the power of a fundamentally new way of developing software systems—fine-tuning. 

GPT-3 (the base model of ChatGPT) was not chatbot-ready “out of the box.” 

Additional training was required to generate responses that provided a helpful UI. This additional training is called fine-tuning. 

Fine-tuning is powerful because by leveraging a pre-trained base model, developers can create better ML models with less data (and thus time and compute). 

I’m excited to see what people build with this.

If you want to build a great business, you need to build great systems, and who better to learn from than the master system builder—Mother Nature 🌱

If you want to build a great business, you need to build great systems, and who better to learn from than the master system builder—Mother Nature 🌱 

Here are 7 Lessons from Nature for Building Better Systems👇 

1. Diversity — monocultures amplify vulnerabilities and weaknesses. 

2. Redundancy — have 2 lungs in case one fails. 

3. Degeneracy — have 2 modules with overlapping functions e.g. you can breathe through your mouth and nose (i.e. diversity + redundancy). 

4. Recycle (everything) — the waste of one is the fuel of another. 

5. Iteration — iteration beats intelligence e.g. it took an army of PhDs to keep up with COVID mutations. 

6. Hierarchical structures — designs span multiple scales e.g. atoms make up molecules, molecules make cells, cells make tissues, tissues make organs, and organs make organisms. 

7. Symmetry  — the left side looks like the right side. today looks like yesterday. the big looks like the small. (special cases: self-similarity and fractals)

👉 Am I missing anything?

I finally found an excuse to try polars (thanks to Ben for showing me the light).

I finally found an excuse to try polars (thanks to Ben for showing me the light). 

For the uninitiated, polars is essentially a (much) faster version of pandas. 

🐻‍❄️ > 🐼 

After using it for a recent project, here are 3 things I liked about it 👇 

1) The Syntax 

Most of the syntax is identical to pandas, which made it super easy to use without any tutorials. 

2) The “Lazy” API 

This allows you to manipulate dataframes without loading them into memory. At the end, you can perform all the operations via the .collect() method. 

3) .scan_parquet() 

Yes, you can import .parquet files in pandas, but when combined with the Lazy API, this allows you to locally work with 10X bigger datasets in polars than pandas

Although the idea of project management might cure insomnia for some data scientists, the more I do projects as an independent, the more I see its value.

Although the idea of project management might cure insomnia for some data scientists, the more I do projects as an independent, the more I see its value. 

This has led me to develop a 5-step project management framework for data science 👇

📌 Phase 0: Problem Definition & Scoping—Formulate the business problem. Design the data science solution. Define project milestones, tasks, and success metrics.

📌 Phase 1: Data Acquisition, Exploration, & Preparation—Evaluate available data. Acquire and explore data. Develop data pipelines. 

📌 Phase 2: Solution Development—Develop ML solution. Evaluate solution validity and value. Iterate with stakeholders and revisit past phases as needed 

📌 Phase 3: Solution Deployment—Integrate solution into real-world business context. Develop solution monitoring pipeline. 

📌 Phase 4: Evaluation & Documentation—Evaluate project outcomes, deliver technical documentation and user guides, and reflect on lessons learned and future work. 

👉 Anything missing here?

Strategy = saying “no” ❌

Strategy = saying “no” ❌ 

There may be a natural inclination toward saying “yes” to every opportunity that comes your way. 

However, this approach inevitably leaves value on the table.

At some point, you have to decide which opportunities are worth pursuing because the value you extract from an opportunity is directly proportional to the amount of resources you devote to it.

This is why saying “no” is one of the most important skills you must learn as an entrepreneur.

I recently said a big “NO” to a major (revenue-generating) part of my business. 

Namely, I stopped taking on AI projects from clients so I could devote more attention to my own product research and development. 

While this may seem like a risk, the bigger risk would be continuing to invest in a line of business that does not serve my long-term goals. 

👉 What is something you can say “no” to next quarter?

I didn't understand "Data Strategy" until I read this article (link in comments).

I didn't understand "Data Strategy" until I read this article (link in comments).

The authors frame data strategy as balancing offensive and defensive efforts.

🗡️ Data offense = Driving Revenue. This tends to be customer-focused (sales and marketing) and more real-time.

🛡️ Data defense = Minimizing risk. This includes ensuring compliance with regulations, fraud detection, and preventing theft, as well as identifying, standardizing, and governing authoritative data sources.

What does "Data Strategy" mean to you? 🤔
