Although LLMs have demonstrated an impressive ability to store and deploy a huge volume of information in response to user queries, compressing knowledge in this way has 2 key limitations 👇

Although LLMs have demonstrated an impressive ability to store and deploy a huge volume of information in response to user queries, compressing knowledge in this way has 2 key limitations 👇 

1) Knowledge is static – the information stored in an LLM is limited to what was available in its training data. 

2) Lack of Specialized Knowledge – LLMs may have an insufficient “understanding“ of niche and domain-specific information that was not prominent in their training data. 

One way we can mitigate these limitations is via Retrieval-augmented Generation (RAG), which augments a model using a specialized and mutable knowledge base 📚

👉 In my latest YouTube video, I provide an overview of key RAG concepts and share a concrete example with Python code 

Check it out and let me know what you think 😁

One of the biggest problems in business is the explore-exploit problem.

One of the biggest problems in business is the explore-exploit problem.

In other words, how much time do we spend on seeking new opportunities vs. sticking to what’s been working?

While the “best” explore-exploit mix depends on the particular situation, one thing is for sure—you need both ✌️

For instance, if I spent all my time reading papers and exploring new product ideas, I would learn a lot (and have fun), but this wouldn’t last very long because it’s unlikely to pay the bills today.

Conversely, if I spent all my time doing consulting engagements and making videos on LLMs, I’d maximize my revenue, but at the cost of my long-term goal of developing a product.

👉 My default solution to this problem is an 80-20 approach, where 80% of my time is spent exploiting and 20% exploring.

How do you solve this problem in your work? 🤔

Here’s the best advice for developing an ML-based project: start simple.

Here’s the best advice for developing an ML-based project: start simple. 

As a recovering “technical” person, I get really excited about sophistication (when I can understand it) 

While this is great for research and big innovation, it often gets you in trouble in a business setting where the goal is often (low-risk) value generation 📈 

This is why the piece of advice I give most often to clients is to start simple (even if that does not include ML) 

Here are a few reasons why you don’t want to start with sophistication 👇 

→ Sophistication = technical debt 
→ More moving parts means a higher chance of failure 
→ Simple is easier (and cheaper) to implement 
→ Simpler models are easier to interpret 

Bonus: Sophistication is especially risky with LLMs because of the rapid pace of innovation. In other words, you can spend 6 months building something that turns out obsolete. 

👉 Anything to add (or remove)? 

#datascience #machinelearning

There are 2 types of data that every data person needs to know about.

There are 2 types of data that every data person needs to know about. 

👉 Thin-tailed and fat-tailed data. 

Thin-tailed are Gaussian-like things 🔔 

📌 They have the key property that no single observation will significantly impact the aggregate statistics, e.g., weight, height, or test scores.

Fat-tailed data, however, are Pareto-like 💸 

📌 Their key property is a single observation that can (and often will) drive the aggregate statistics, e.g., wealth, sales, and pandemics.

There are 2 types of data that every data scientist needs to know about.

There are 2 types of data that every data scientist needs to know about. 

These are what author Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls Mediocristan and Extremistan. 

Mediocristan is the land of Gaussian-like things 🔔 

This type of data has the property that no single observation will significantly impact the aggregate statistics e.g. weight, height, test scores. 

The other type of data is from Extremistan, which is the land of power laws (i.e. a Pareto distribution) 🙅 

In contrast to Mediocrostan, in Extremistan, a single observation can (and often will) drive the aggregate statistics e.g. wealth, sales, pandemics. 

This map visualizes different distributions across this conceptual landscape 👇

You’ve probably heard of the so-called “80–20 rule,” i.e. “80% of sales come from 20% of customers”.

This idea (qualitatively) pops up in many other quantities e.g. wealth 💰, city populations 🏙️ , deaths in pandemics 🦠, and more.

For example, the heights of adult males (i.e. a Gaussian distribution) are not fat-tailed, while the incomes of adult males (i.e. a Pareto-like distribution) are.

Hot take—Don’t study generative AI 🔥

Hot take—Don’t study generative AI 🔥

Those early in their career have asked me, “What’s the best degree for breaking into AI?” 🤔

While I don’t think there is a “best” path that works for everyone, there are more fragile paths than others. 

Here’s my rule of thumb—when trying to establish foundational knowledge, the older the subject, the better 📕>📱

This is based on something called the Lindy Principle, which says the “life expectancy” of a field is proportional to its current age. 

For example—math has been around for ~5,000 years, so Lindy says it’ll be around for a few more millennia 🤓

Conversely, ”Generative AI” has been around for ~1 year, so odds are it’ll be around for another year or so 🤖

This is the most significant innovation in machine learning.

This is the most significant innovation in machine learning. 

Back in the day (i.e. ~5 years ago), if you wanted to build a model, you needed to ask—how can I label training data at scale? 😮‍💨 

However, in today’s ML landscape, you might ask yourself a different question—what existing models could I fine-tune? 🔧  

Fine-tuning is taking an existing model and tweaking it for a particular use case. 

👉 The key upside of this approach is that models can achieve better performance while requiring (far) fewer manually labeled examples. 

For example, OpenAI’s InstructGPT models were fine-tuned from GPT-3 using ~10,000X fewer tokens, yet the models demonstrate significantly better performance 📈

But this isn’t limited to LLMs...

And with the rich ecology of ML models available these days, building a niche state-of-the-art model has never been more accessible 🚀

Last week, I was invited to be part of a panel discussion hosted by Data Science Club at UTDallas.

Last week, I was invited to be part of a panel discussion hosted by Data Science Club at UTDallas.

The discussion was geared toward aspiring data scientists and how to break into the field. 

One of the key talking points was the importance of getting real-world experience to increase your chances of landing a DS role 📈 

However, this can often bring up the (frustrating) story of “you need experience to get a job, but you need a job to get experience.” 

To help resolve this, here are 5 ways to become a data scientist beyond (prior) work experience 👇 

1) Education 🤓 — Most data scientists I’ve met have some additional training beyond an undergraduate degree. 

2) Independent Projects 🧑‍💻— An effective (and cost-free) way to learn is to pursue independent projects you find interesting with data from the real world. 

3) Content Creation ✍️ — Make content about data science topics and projects. I find this is not only a great way to learn but also a great way to show your skills and competence. 

4) LinkedIn (networking) 🧑‍💼— Simply being more active on LinkedIn is a great way to increase your exposure to peers and potential employers. A key point is that you may not necessarily need to develop your skills further. Simply conveying the skills you already have might be enough. 

5) Freelancing 🤝 — This is a personal favorite for me. Even if you don’t get any contracts, the pace of freelance contracts is much faster than full-time roles. This means you get many more reps fine-tuning your resume, writing cover letters, and doing interviews freelancing than otherwise.

While fine-tuning a model is much cheaper (financially and computationally) than building one from scratch, retraining all the parameters in a large language model can still be a tremendous undertaking.

While fine-tuning a model is much cheaper (financially and computationally) than building one from scratch, retraining all the parameters in a large language model can still be a tremendous undertaking. 

This is where so-called Parameter Efficient Fine-tuning (PEFT) methods have become critical for practitioners 🧑‍💻 

One of the most popular PEFT methods is Low-Rank Adaptation or LoRA for short. 

👉 LoRA fine-tunes an existing model by adding a (small) set of trainable parameters while keeping all the original parameters fixed. 

This can result in 100X reduction in the number of trainable parameters without sacrificing performance 🤯 

I talk more about LoRA in a recent YouTube video all about fine-tuning LLMs. 

Here is a clip from the video 👇 

#AI #LLM #generativeAI #ML

This is getting rid of full-time jobs (and it isn’t AI).

This is getting rid of full-time jobs (and it isn’t AI). 

When we were all forced to work from home by COVID, many people started to think about work differently 🤔

One of the more extreme versions of this was the trend of people taking on 2 (or even 3) full-time jobs 😮

While I won’t comment on the ethics of this, it does raise a question for our current working paradigm. 

How is it possible for someone to work 120 hours a week to do 3 full-time jobs? 

Well.. they can't.

The worst-kept secret of our current full-time work paradigm is that most people are not engaged in their work. 

And while full-time roles are typically a 40-hour-a-week time commitment on paper, the reality of what people actually do is often much less than that. 

A solution to this problem, which has been on the rise since 2020, is remote part-time work i.e. the gig economy 📈

This replaces the 40-hour workweek idea for something more flexible and beneficial to both employees and employers.

Employees, since they have more control over their time and attention, can optimize their work for their unique values and goals. 

Employers, since they can rely more on temporary part-time workers, can have more flexible staffing and close the gap between wages paid and hours worked. 

👉 While I don’t think a complete gig economy is feasible or optimal, I do believe more independent workers will lead to a more resilient and productive economy. 

What do you think? Is freelance work just a fad? 

#work #freelance #gigeconomy #fulltime

However, after diving into it more deeply, I’ve changed my perspective. 

I now view it as a new programming paradigm that changes how developers can build applications 🚀

Before, the programmer had to define every inch of logic in their software system. 

Now, however, the constraints are more relaxed. 

👉 If there is some sub-task that the programmer doesn’t want to (or know how to) program, they can readily prompt an LLM to fill in the gaps in their code.

I believe this is a window to a future where computation is as widely accessible as reading and writing 👨🏻‍💻

One of the most exciting parts of this has been the blossoming open-source LLM community for which Hugging Face has become a major hub. 

There are 4 key elements of the Hugging Face ecosystem that all developers should know about 🧑‍💻 

1) Models - a growing repository of over 250,000 open-source ML models 
2) Datasets - a library of datasets to train and fine-tune models 
3) Spaces - Git repositories that host open-source ML applications

Imbalanced data presents a challenge in machine learning when one class label occurs much less frequently than another.

Imbalanced data presents a challenge in machine learning when one class label occurs much less frequently than another. 

For instance, training a model to differentiate between sick and healthy patients might have only 1% sick patients in the data 🤕 

The common issue is that classifiers trained on imbalanced data tend to “over-predict” the majority class, resulting in high accuracy 📈 but poor performance on the minority class 📉 

One approach to address this is resampling the data to balance it, either by oversampling the minority class or undersampling the majority class ⚖️ 

However, this may lead to a mismatch between the training data distribution and the real-world distribution. 

An alternative solution is Cost-Sensitive Learning, which involves weighting different misclassification errors based on their real-world costs 💰 

By incorporating the real-world costs of false positives and false negatives in model development, this technique can overcome the imbalanced data problem without altering the training data distribution. 

To explore this further, there is a great paper on the topic by 
Charles X. Ling and Victor S. Sheng. 

*** 

Any thoughts on Cost-Sensitive Learning compared to other techniques for handling imbalanced data?

#datascience #machinelearning #AI

Can Topological Data Analysis (TDA) predict the next market crash? 🤔📉

Can Topological Data Analysis (TDA) predict the next market crash? 🤔📉

TDA is an analysis approach that looks at the “shape” of data.

💡 The idea is to consider topological features of data that are more robust to noise than more traditional statistical quantities (e.g. mean, median, variance)

One popular use case is using TDA to analyze noisy market data (e.g. stocks and indexes) 📈📉

Inspired by Gidea and Katz 2017 (arXiv:1703.04385 [q-fin.MF]), I evaluated how changes in topological features tracked with the S&P 500.

The results were surprising 😮

The chart below shows S&P 500 prices (orange) along with changes in the “shape” of 4 market indexes (blue).

What’s surprising is we see an uptick in the blue curve (i.e. market shape changes) weeks before the “Crash of 2020”.

Topological Data Analysis (TDA) analyzes the “shape” of data 🔺▪️🔸

Topological Data Analysis (TDA) analyzes the “shape” of data 🔺▪️🔸

One popular TDA apporach is Persistent Homology.

The theory behind Persistent Homology can be difficult to grasp when first learning it (was for me anyway) 🤔🤷🏻‍♂️

But when you break it down, there are 3 key pieces to it 🔑

1️⃣ Triangles (i.e. simplexes) — the great thing about triangles is we can use them to construct any polygon.

This makes triangles a special case of the more general idea of a simplex 🔺

2️⃣ Simplical Complexes — if we have collections of simplexes (e.g. triangles) we get what’s called a simplical complex 🔺🔻🔺

It turns out, we can translate data into a simiplical complex 📊 ➡️ 🔻🔺🔻

3️⃣ Holes — with data converted into this simplical complex thingy, we can characterize its shape by couting the number of holes it has.

However, in true math fashion, we don’t just consider the (1D) holes we all know and love from donuts and coffe mugs 🍩☕️

We also consider 0-dimensional and 2-dimensional “holes” i.e. connected components 🪨 and cavities 🏀, respectively.

These generalized holes are called homology groups, which is where the name “Persistent Homology” comes from.

It helps to visualize these concepts, which is why I made a YouTube video walking through this more intuitive explaination of Persistent Homology.

Check it out here 👇

#TDA #topologicaldataanalysis #datascience #dataanalysis #data #math #shape #homology

Independent Component Analysis (ICA) extracts hidden factors from data by transforming the variables to a new, maximally independent set 🔍

Independent Component Analysis (ICA) extracts hidden factors from data by transforming the variables to a new, maximally independent set 🔍 

A popular application of this is removing eye blinks from EEG data. 
👁️👁️ 

Electroencephalography (EEG) is a brain imaging technique consisting of an array of electrodes placed on the scalp 🧠 

Since these brain signals are so weak, EEG needs to pick up very small changes in electrical activity 🔬 

One downside of this is that eye blinks create artifacts in EEG signals. 

This can be seen in the 1️⃣st time series below, where eye blinks appear as prominent peaks in the EEG signal. 

👉 One way to handle these artifacts is by applying ICA to the EEG data and removing all components corresponding to eye blinks. 

The final output of this process is shown in the 2️⃣nd time series below. 

Here we capture the signal oscillations but without the blink artifacts 😎

The Cocktail Party Problem? 🤔🍸

The Cocktail Party Problem? 🤔🍸

This is a standard problem used to describe Independent Component Analysis (ICA).

👉 Set-up: Imagine two people conversing at a cocktail party 🗣️🗣️

You, for whatever reason, have two microphones placed near both party-goers 🎙️🎙️

However, you realize your recordings are mixed up with both speakers’ voices on playback.

👉 Problem: How can we isolate each speaker's voice from our two recordings?

👉 Solution: Independent Component Analysis (ICA)

ICA transforms a set of signals into a maximally independent set ✅

We can convert the two mixed audio recordings into two isolated recordings of each speaker.

This is shown visually in the image below where the (mixed) purple and pink waveforms ➡️ (unmixed) blue and red waveforms.

Imagine a big rock band 🤘

Imagine a big rock band 🤘

Guitarists, singers, pianists, horns, keyboards, drummers, bass players, etc. 

A big band needs a big stage, which is not a problem for venues like Madison Square Garden, but what if they are just starting out and can only play local coffee shops? ☕️

Well, instead of 3 guitars, there could just be one. 
🎸🎸🎸 ➡️ 🎸

Instead of 2 drummers and a percussionist, one could play the bongos. 
🥁🥁🥁 ➡️🪘

And instead of a piano, electric piano, and accordian on stage, one member could play a keyboard.
 🎹🎹🪗 ➡️ 🎹

You wouldn’t get the full detail of each song, but the songs could still be played in an MTV unplugged kind of way.

This is exactly what happens when using Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

But instead of a band, we have data 👨🏻‍💻

Instead of players, we have variables 📈

And instead of a song, we have what the data represent 🤔

Taking the analogy further..

Data often have redundant variables (like having 3 background vocalists)

Sometimes you need them all, but many times you do not.

And just like we can rewrite music for a smaller band, PCA can re-represent our data with fewer variables.

Put another way, PCA rewrites the “music” so that fewer “players” can perform the same “song” 😁

***

When was the last time you used PCA?

A remarkable thing happens when many simple models (i.e. weak learners) are merged into a single model 😮

A remarkable thing happens when many simple models (i.e. weak learners) are merged into a single model 😮

Although the model is more “complex” it seems to be more robust against overfitting 🤯

This is an empirical result seen from decision tree ensembles 🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲

Tree ensembles combine many decision trees into a single model.

2️⃣ popular ways do this are:

Bagging 🛍️ (i.e. Bootstrap AGGregatING) - this is where we generate several decision trees by sampling a single dataset multiple times with replacement

Boosting 🚀 - this is where we recursively re-weight a dataset based on decision tree performance

These ideas underlie popular methods such as Random Forest, AdaBoost, Gradient Boosting, and XGBoost.

I talk more about bagging, boosting, and tree ensembles in my latest YouTube video linked below 👇

How can we do more with less? 🤷‍♂️

How can we do more with less? 🤷‍♂️ 

A fundamental problem for anyone trying to be productive is getting the most out of your limited time and resources. 

To do this.. some may find themselves multitasking. 

But multitasking makes it hard for your brain to perform well and learn new things 🤕 

Instead, we can learn from our bird-hating ancestors and try to “kill 2 birds with 1 stone” 

While this may sound similar to multitasking, it has a key difference. 

❌ Multitasking is doing two things at the same(-ish) time. 

👉 However, “killing two birds with one stone” is different. 

It’s a single effort (stone), resulting in two outcomes (dead birds). 

Sorry birdies. 🦤🦤  🪨💨 

Generalizing this latter idea brings up what I call a “Multikill” 

A multikill = a single effort that results in multiple desired outcomes. 

Multikills amplify productivity. 🚀 

Unlike multitasking, they are a scalable way to get more out of your time ⌚️, resources 💵, and brain 🧠. 

Don’t multitask, multikill.

What the heck is a wavelet? 🤔

What the heck is a wavelet? 🤔

Wavelets were one of those things I had always heard in passing but never fully understood.

Until I came across the problem of analyzing ECG data🫀

So… 2 questions

1) What’s a wavelet?

2) Why is it helpful?

1️⃣ A wavelet is a wave-like oscillation localized in time.

These come in many shapes and sizes, as shown in the picture below 👇 

We can use them to do something called a Wavelet Transform.

This is like the Fourier Transform from previous posts, but instead of decomposing a signal into sines and cosines 🔉, we decompose it into a set of wavelets.

2️⃣ This is helpful for ECG analysis because heart beats are localized events (like a wavelet)

Thus, one can use the wavelet transform to detect pulses in ECG data more readily than other signal processing techniques 😁

“The world’s most important algorithm” 🏆 

I recently shared a post about the Fourier Transform and how it is used for things like audio production, analyzing brain activity, and high-quality video compression. 

But.. the Fourier Transform (FT) would never have had the impact it did if it was not for a special algorithm.. 

The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) 🏎️💨 

The FFT sped up a O(N^2) task to a O(N*log(N)) task. 

What does that mean?? 🤔 

Well.. if we apply a Discrete FT to our favoriate 3 min pop song, that would require about 10^13 computations (that’s a 1 with 13 zeros after it) 🐢 

But with the FFT this comes down to 10^8 computations, which is 10,000x faster! 🤯

Typically the best way to estimate causal effects are through interventional studies that employ randomization.

Typically the best way to estimate causal effects are through interventional studies that employ randomization. 

However, sometimes such studies are not feasible ❌ 

In such cases, we may want to estimate causal effects from observational data 🔎

One way we can do this is by using propensity scores. 

💊 A propensity score estimates the probability that a subject receives treatment based on other characteristics 

3 Ways to Use Propensity Scores to estimate causal effects ⬇️ 

1️⃣ 1:1 Matching — create treated-control pairs with similar propensity scores 

2️⃣ Stratification — split subjects into groups with similar propensity scores

3️⃣ Inverse probability of treatment weighting (IPTW) — use propensity scores to derive weights for each subject which can be used to compute treatment effects directly  

***

But, what if doing an RCT is.. 

Unethical 🚬 : Causal effect of smoking a pack a day on cardiovascular health? 

💊 Treatment - smoke a pack of cigarettes a day
🚫 Control - no smoking 

Unfeasible 🏀: Causal effect of height on basketball performance? 

💊 Treatment - grow 3 inches
🚫 Control - no change in height 

👉 This is where estimating causal effects from observational data is beneficial. 

One method we can use to help estimate causal effects is a Propensity Score. 

What is a Propensity Score? 🤔 

👉 A propensity score is the (estimated) probability that an individual received treatment based on other characteristics. 

We can use propensity scores in many ways to help estimate causal effects. 

I discuss 3 such techniques in a blog post and YouTube video. (Link in Comments)

A book 📕 that changed how I see the world is Antifragile by Nassim Taleb (no relation)

A book 📕 that changed how I see the world is Antifragile by Nassim Taleb (no relation) 

In it, the author defines the concept of ANTI-fragility. 

🤔 What’s the difference between FRAGILITY and ANTIFRAGILITY? 

Well… 

Fragile 🍸 = something that is harmed by disorder, variability, or errors 

Antifragile 🐈 = something that benefits from disorder, variability, or errors 

Here are some examples 📝 (many from the book) 

Fragile → champagne glasses, your washing machine, economic forecasts, “too big to fail”, classroom learning, E-readers 

Antifragile → your cat, your nervous system, heuristics/rules-of-thumb, start-ups, learning by doing, oral tradition 

In a world 🌎 better characterized by uncertainty than certainty, being (at least a little) antifragile sounds like a good idea 

***

What is something Antifragile in your life? Leave a comment below 👇

📣  How data are measured matters.

📣  How data are measured matters.

-

Here are 2️⃣  ways data are obtained.

🔍  1) Observational Studies:

This consists of passively measuring a system without any intervention in the data-generating process.

(Most data are like this)

🪛  2) Interventional/Experimental Studies:

This is when we purposely influence the data-generating process for a particular goal.

Example: Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs)

🤔 Why does this matter?

When using observational data, we must look out for systematic differences between treatment and control groups.

A key tool central to interventional studies that helps combat this issue is randomization.

Randomization helps ensure there are no systematic differences between treated 💊 and control 🚫 groups.
